Authors:
Ryoko Oono, Emilie LeFevre, Anita Simha, Francois
Lutzoni
Title:
A comparison of the community diversity of foliar fungal
endophytes between seedling and adult loblolly pines (Pinus taeda)
Keywords:
Class 3 endophytes, fungal communities, phylogeny, Pinus
taeda, plant-fungal symbiosis
Abstract:
Fungal endophytes represent one of the most ubiquitous
plant symbionts on Earth and are phylogenetically diverse. The structure
and diversity of endophyte communities have been shown to depend mostly
on host taxa and climate, but there are relatively few studies exploring
the effects of host maturity. We compared foliar fungal endophyte
communities between seedlings and adult trees of loblolly pines (Pinus
taeda) at the same seasons and locations by culturing and
culture-independent methods. We sequenced the internal transcribed
spacer region and adjacent partial large subunit nuclear ribosomal RNA
gene (ITS-LSU amplicon) to delimit operational taxonomic units and
phylogenetically characterize the communities. Despite the lower
infection frequency in seedlings compared to adult trees, seedling
needles were receptive to a more diverse community of fungal endophytes.
Culture-free methods confirmed the presence of commonly cultured OTUs
from adult needles but revealed several new OTUs from seedling needles
that were not found with culturing methods. The two most commonly
cultured OTUs in adults were rarely cultured from seedlings, suggesting
that host age is associated with a selective enrichment for specific
endophytes. This shift in endophyte species dominance may be indicative
of a functional change between these fungi and their loblolly pine
hosts.
